name: A. Reachable Numbers
statement:
Let’s denote a function f(x) in such a way: we add 1 to x, then, while
there is at least one trailing zero in the resulting number, we remove
that zero. For example, f(599) = 6: 599 + 1 = 600
rightarrow 60
rightarrow 6; f(7) = 8: 7 + 1 = 8; f(9) = 1: 9 + 1 = 10
rightarrow 1; f(10099) = 101: 10099 + 1 = 10100
rightarrow 1010
rightarrow 101. We say that some number y is from x if we can apply
function f to x some (possibly zero) times so that we get y as a result.
For example, 102 is reachable from 10098 because f(f(f(10098))) =
f(f(10099)) = f(101) = 102; and any number is reachable from itself.You
are given a number n; your task is to count how many different numbers
are reachable from n.
editorial:
The key fact in this problem is that the answer is not very large (in
fact, itâs not greater than ). Why is it so? Every times we apply
function to our current number, it gets divided by (at least), and the
number of such divisions is bounded as .So we can just do the following:
store all reachable numbers somewhere, and write a loop that adds
current number to reachable numbers, and sets (we should end this loop
when already belongs to reachable numbers). The most convenient way to
store reachable numbers is to use any data structure from your favourite
programming language that implemenets a set, but, in fact, the
constrains were so small that it was possible to store all reachable
numbers in an array.
